review:
The Galaxy Tab E is just what I wanted in a large screen tablet for my everyday use that was not very expensive but still perfectly capable.  I realized a while ago that even though I love tablets my actual use in no way justified spending hundreds of dollars on a top of the line model - not for browsing the Internet, watching YouTube videos, writing, and reading.  I also like to take my tablet with me everywhere - trips, work, and places I can sit and do some writing - so an affordable one is just way more practical.  Ive used small size tablets for a while but found myself missing a big screen, something in the around 10 inch size, but finding something with good enough performance at that size without spending quite a bit was difficult.  Enter the Tab E.

From my use of it I feel Samsung has struck a good balance between price and features with this one.  There are a couple of areas where you can tell compromises were made for the sake of affordability but for a general use tablet if a big screen matters to you this one is hard to beat.

Great things about the Tab E:
-The screen is big, colorful, and responsive.
-Performance is absolutely stellar considering the price.  Everything is smooth, apps open quickly, switching between apps is fluid, and even running two apps at once works with minimal slowdown.  It has handled everything I have thrown at it with no problem and never a freeze or even a hiccup.  I was able to use it while it was installing and downloading multiple apps and updates when I first got it and not really notice.
-It is running a very recent version of Android - 5.1.1.  You have all your Google applications and everything you would expect from the operating system.
-The shape is really nice.  This is a very rectangular tablet.  Widescreen is great for video watching and it is comfortable to hold.  It is not a big square slab like my old Tab 4.
-It looks good and feels very solid.  It has some substance to it.  Some might call it a bit thick or bulky but I like its solid feeling and it certainly does not seem cheap.  It is missing the usual bright metal strip around the outside edge of the tablet but I like the more uniform all black matte look used here.  The back has a grippy textured molding.  Mine is in a case so I don't notice this much but it would not be slick or easily dropped without a case.  All buttons (home, volume, power) feel solid and very clicky.
-Battery life has been excellent.  I charged it full the day I got it and it was not until three days later I needed to charge it again and this was after considerable use.
-There is an SD card slot for video storage to supplement the 16GB of internal memory.  I think 16GB it a little limited but expect it at this price.  The SD card slot makes it workable.
-Wifi connection is strong.  It gets full signal anywhere in my apartment and it both loads websites and downloads content quickly.

Is is for Economy.  Less good things to keep in mind:
-While the screen is big and colorful it does not seem as high a quality overall compared to other tablets Ive owned from Samsung.  The resolution is not bad at 1200x800, which is really what I expected for the price.  However, you can basically see a pattern of thin lines throughout that just says budget display.  It is hard to describe what this looks like and it is not a defect as Ive seen three of these tablets (my own and two local display units) and the screens all look the same.  The screen is fine, just seems like cheaper/older/etc. tech.
-The speaker Every review has mentioned the sound.  I was expecting worse, considering.  The sound really isn't THAT bad, a little tinny, but the problem is with the placement of the speaker.  There is one speaker and it is on the back of the tablet near the camera facing away from you.  I really won't get why it was designed this way.  I have a case that folds over and I find this helps redirect the sound towards the user.  If you want to seriously listen to music I would recommend headphones or a bluetooth speaker,  It is fine for streaming video as far as Im concerned.
-Some might find this tablet too thick or heavy.  It is not super thin and weighs a little over a pound.

Overall I would absolutely recommend this tablet if you want something budget friendly but a large screen is important to you.  I did not really discuss camera but I just don't use the cameras on tablets, especially large tablets, so I don't really have an opinion.  Keep in mind it is a bit heavy and the sound is average.  At this price for a well performing tablet from a name brand like Samsung  the Tab E is a very good choice.  This is a basic tablet experience - no bells and whistles but smooth performance and function.  I am very happy with mine.
Good tablet for the price.  Speakers are poor.

Please take my review with a grain of salt; this is my first tablet of my own.
I've had this tablet for about a week and a half at the time of this review. My purpose for purchasing it was to have a convenient device for college use, and, I'm not going to lie, to have some fun with it by watching videos and listening to music. For the price, it's everthing I could have hoped for. It runs at a decent speed, has great screen quality, and has a lot of great features. It comes with Microsoft Word, Excel and Powerpoint, which is a huge plus for me. I can sync music directly with Windows Media Player, which is  a huge relief since I don't have to wrestle with the travesty that is called iTunes. The internet reception is strong, and the device is bluetooth-capable.
The camera quality is decent. In fact, my iPhone has a better camera than this device does, but I don't find it to be that bad.
The speakers, though, are the biggest drawback. Pretty bad quality; very tinny. I recommend listening to media with headphones or a bluetooth speaker.
Media, such as videos on YouTube and Netflix, work without a hitch. The screen quality is great.
Another plus: this tablet just LOOKS good. Samsung does a good job of making their tablets aesthetically pleasing, and this is no exception. Very sleek and eye-catching design, and feels good in your hands.
This tablet isn't the fanciest or highest-performing tablet out there, but it's all I need for school and general media use, and I'm very satisfied with it. It does everything I could ask of it.

If you're a smart buyer and read all of the 1-star reviews when considering a product, read on.  Shame on me for not doing the same.  I am the father of a family of 5, two of my children are autistic and live and die by their tablets.  I have had many tablets over the years, literally dozens, the vast majority Samsung as they generally build a quality product at a sensible price.  Do not let the attractive price of the Galaxy Tab E lure you in.  I purchased this item to replace a Galaxy Tab A that was left out in a rain storm and I have never been more disappointed in a purchase.  It looks the part, and it seems as well built as any other Samsung tablet, but calling it under-powered is an understatement of epic proportion.  So much so, that it couldn't even play half of my daughter's children's games.  Talking pet games would hang eternally upon startup.  Everything was super-slow and laggy,  YouTube would take minutes to load so I assumed I received a defective item.  I performed three factory resets but nothing helped.  It was only then that I looked at the 1-star reviews and found that what I was experiencing was typical for this unit.  It is just a current tablet that performs worse than my 4-year old Galaxy Tab 3 Lite which was a budget unit then.  I ultimately packed up and returned the Galaxy Tab E, eating the 20% restock fee and found a used, like new Galaxy Tab A for the same price and my kid is happy once again.  Stay away from this turd, increase your budget, or try to find a used Galaxy Tab A as I did.  If I save one of you from massive disappointment, my job is done.

This was going to be my first tablet, and I was looking forward to the flexibility it would give me to step away from my computer and stop squinting at my phone.  I planned to use it just for general web browsing and email, sitting on my couch, on the porch, etc.  However, this device is so big and so heavy, I found it very uncomfortable to use the way I had hoped.  It's definitely not a one-handed device, and you will want to have it resting on a table top, knee, or lap (so get a good case for it).  The extra length for the wide aspect ratio is fine in landscape mode, but it makes it top heavy to hold in portrait mode, even with both hands.  I also found I didn't need the extra screen space.

I was disappointed in the screen display quality, too.  I found the icons to be slightly fuzzy, and the color was not great.  I'm a hobbyist photographer, and I thought this device might be useful to occasionally share some photos with family and friends on a nice portable screen.  But the color quality just wasn't adequate for that, and resolution was disappointing.  Another minor flaw, but very annoying, there is no auto-brightness.  I found myself constantly adjusting the brightness setting.

So after trying this device for a few days, I gave up and ordered a Tab A 8".  It's MUCH lighter (feels like half the weight of the Tab E 9.6") and easy to hold, the screen color is right on, display quality is sharp, and there's even auto-brightness.  I found my match.

This tablet has a 7200 mAh battery (not 5000 as shown in places including gsmarena) which, when combined with modest specs (lower res screen and slower processor) and the nougat update (7.1.1) makes for one of the longest lasting tablets I have ever owned. I am willing to give up processing power and resolution if it means I can watch four movies on a plane and arrive at my destination with 50% battery left. Those modest specs means this is not a great gaming tablet or something you want to use to stream to your smart TV. What it is ideal for is something small enough to easy pack with a big enough screen to get some work done (I use google apps) and watch some shows to relax. Pros for me: Long battery life, nice size screen, not too bulky, good OS and skin from Samsung. Cons for me: poor speaker. some stuttering in performance under high demand (just close background apps).

This is a basic, but good, all around tablet. It's features and specs are on their website. But from a 'usability' point of view:

1st and foremost, this is a low resolution display. If you look closely, icons, text, etc are a tiny bit fuzzy. To me, that's okay for most all of what I do with a tablet. And, I believe it probably helps with battery life.

2nd, you have to decide on which aspect ratio you want. This is a 16x9, another popular choice is 4x3 (like IPads). I tried some of the 4x3 and just find them 'un-wieldy' (you almost need some kind of stand for them, they don't really fit in your lap securely). The Tab E 9.6 screen size, and in 16x9 ratio, is ideal imho.

3rd, and again it's personal choice / needs, as this is at the low end of processing power, so it's not considered a 'gaming device'. But if you only run a few apps, a browser, solitaire, things of that nature, and with the slightly less crisp resolution, this tablet should be close to top of your list.

Strange to open with this, but I bought this so I could browse /watch YouTube, etc, and my girlfriend could do the same on the laptop. When this was in transit, I considered canceling once it arrived because between the two of us, two smartphones a laptop and then now a tablet seemed excessive. I bought this without informing her upfront but I was surprised with how glad she was I did. We actually both agree it was a good investment. After a long day of work, we both like to decompress and part ways for a while on most nights (her in the bedroom, me in the living room) and we now each have devices to stream versus waiting to revive our nearly dead phones. I'm not here to really get into specs, but rather my input on using a tablet for a few months now compared to the laptop we shared:
Pros: it's like a giant version of an interface I've used since 2012...galaxy series. Nothing to "learn"
The battery is a beast. I'm not screwed the next day if I forget to plug it in before bed.
It's more portable /less clunky to take into another room (say to do dishes and watch a video)
The screen seems very large for a tablet at this price point.
Some see this as a con, but it's surprisingly heavy. It feels like a solid, legitimate piece of tech.
Cons:
No case (I've tried two) are going to be perfect. The ability to adjust viewing angle basically depends on how long you're willing to hold the tablet at that position. I still go for the laptop laying in bed.
The bottom buttons can been easily hit when holding the tablet and even though you can rotate in all 4 directions, I still find myself bumping those buttons often unintentionally no matter where they are.
The keyboard is pressure sensitive, versus heat sensitive, which doesn't seem like a big deal, except I've many a time found myself bumping my headphone cord changing a screen and the heel of my thumb hitting the enter button in vertical mode which leads to my next point...
Typing. Horizontal or vertical, typing is inconvenient. A cell phone or laptop keyboard is literally 10 times faster and more tactile. I'd love to meet someone that legitimately types out full documents on any tablet.
Lastly, the back side. The speak is poorly placed, more quiet than any device I own and is easily covered by cases, hands etc. The camera is okay (it has a front facing as well) but have never really understood nor seen the use of rear facing cameras on tablets.

Don't waster your money! The tablet has hardware problems as it is constantly shutting down. This tablet worked great for about 10 months and then it began freezing, restarting (sometimes caught in a loop), and now finally shutting down 2 months later.  It was tested with an oscilloscope showing a severe drop in voltage as it unexpectedly shut down, which may be faulty soldering. Hours were spent trying to identify if applications were causing the restarting and after several reset to factory settings, the problems still exist. The next step is checking to see if it is an issue with the battery or circuit board. In either case, this tablet is no longer functional until it is disassembled and repaired by a professional. Google search "Samsung restarting" to find many customers with the same problem!

Purchased this tablet and I enjoy the sturdy feel.

Pros: It is solidly built and has a vivid display this is smooth. The rectangular shape is awesome for Hulu, Amazon Prime, Netflix,etc. It makes for an excellent Kindle/ebook Reader as well. Nice for any browsing on the web.

I also have a season subscription to MLB at bat. Watching live sports is crystal clear with stunning detail. I cannot wait for NFL Sunday ticket.

Con: as of 4-16-17, the tablet updates to the latest Android operating system which is Android 6.0.1. A key feature is the ability to set up more than one user account. Problem is this can be accessed on the lock screen before your passcode is entered. I attached a photo to demonstrate. Anyone who picks up the tablet can add a guest account and go into google play store, input their email, download apps, not on your dime but still, surf the web, even see photos you took under your account. There is no way to change this drop down menu to just have one user, yours!

So just be careful where you leave your tablet. Another issue related to this device settings is that the notification panel can also be pulled down at the lock screen. A thief can turn on airplane mode. This no doubt makes it more difficult to find your tablet with no internet connection. So even if you installed Samsung find my tablet or Android Device Manager it won't do much good because those  services require an internet connection.

I am going to see if a Geek Squad agent can solve those two issues on lock screen: disabling guest accounts and the ability to pull down notification panel. I will update anything I find out.

Update: I consulted Geek Squad Agent and there is nothing they can do. It is part of the makeup of the tablet baked into its settings with no way to solve either issue. I also went to Best Buy and talked with the Samsung rep who also was not aware of this issue. She promised to look into it but could not find a way in the settings to fix either issue.

UPDATE: 3/26/18- I installed the latest software update and it fixed both those security issues. No access to guest account from lock screen and no access to wifi toggle or airplane mode from lock screen. Thank you Samsung!

The camera is poor. 5 mega pixals does not get you much. I realize they had to trim down some bells and whistles on this device so camera is not too much of an issue for me.

Sound is poor. Speaker is located on the back so volume travels away from you. If speaker was on the side or bottom of the device it would be much louder!

Overall some flaws in design, but I am happy with larger screen and happy that lock screen security issues were fixed by latest update.

Prior to owning this Tab E 9.6, the only other tablet I owned was the original Motorola Xoom which was a first-gen device with a lot of little drawbacks. It ended up being more of a toy. Otherwise I have been a smart phone + laptop guy for the past 5 years. Never found a real need for a tablet.

Fast-forward - I purchased the 2016 model with 16gig memory, 1.5gig RAM and the 7600mah battery / non-cellular model. Basically I started traveling internationally a lot in the past year and wanted to carry less stuff... mainly mags and books that take up a bunch of space. Yes, I am a very late convert to reading mags and books digitally and now I am hooked. I also added a 128gig microSD card to hold a whole bunch of books, mags, movies and music. Right now this device is pretty much my mobile entertainment hub.

I think I paid about $180 for the tablet, $20 for the microSD and $10 for a case. It's been very handy. 1080p movies in multiple fomats play fine (mp4, mkv, avi). NOT AMUSED.  This quote from the product description is an outright lie:  "The Galaxy Tab E was made to go wherever you go and do whatever you want to do."  I've had this Tab E device for several months.  1)  The charge is intermittent.  Sometimes the battery drains very fast, faster than the device will charge.  Samsung tech support went through settings to optimize the battery longevity.  Charging remained a problem.  2)  Tapping the screen does not consistently excecute a command, such as closing a window or switching between windows.  I was told this is related to memory.  This is a new device.  Only Line Messenger is loaded on it.  And Samsung tech support helped optimize settings with apps.  So why would memory be a problem?  3)  I bought this device in the United States.  Soon I will be traveling to South Africa.  The largest internet service provider in the area I will be traveling to in South Africa lists the Samsung Tab E as a compatible device.  Yet Samsung does not sell a power adapter plug or voltage converter so I can use the tablet in South Africa, nor does anyone (throughout 6 calls) know who does sell these two items for any country that uses this device.  The last Samsung representative suggested I peruse Amazon for the necessary adapter and converter.  If consistent training for product function, requirements, and accessory availability were consistent, that would have been said during the first call.  However unsatisfactory an answer it is, I would not have wasted time calling Samsung over and over.  4)  When I called about this 3rd issue, I spent approximately an hour and a half, including hold times, across 6 calls.  Three times Samsung wanted me to talk with their Accessories department / parts distributor J & J(?).  I did not call J & J(?) a second or third time because J & J(?) was as frustrated as I am, that Samsung transferred me to them for the first call.  J & J(?) does not have a power plug adapter or voltage converter and they don't know why Samsung referred me to them to purchase these items.  I was told to call tech support, Sales, Accessories, and to consult the Samsung website (which I did before making the first call).  5)  Some notifications for apps are invisible?  No matter where I looked in Settings, notifications for some apps simply will not turn off.  I won't be buying another Samsung product for a long time no matter how good it sounds.

I have counted on a tablet for the last 6 years and use it daily for work.  I work in the field and rely on the portability of a tablet rather than a laptop.  Even though I still need a laptop for certain applications, I have used a Motorola Xoom for the last  six years.  The Galaxy has been a very nice and affordable replacement to the Xoom.  My Galaxy does not have cellular capability, but I can wifi through my external hotspot while in the field.  The Galaxy pros: very affordable, very fast, SD card capable for extra storage.  Cons: as all tabs, there is no USB ports which is a pain and the touch controls get in the way and cause you to exit out and sometimes delete what you are working on.  All in all, it suits my needs.

I'll give you the tl;dr version first:
If you want a basic tablet to browse the internet, watch videos and play games, it's good value. If you need a productivity device, you might want to try a different brand.

I got this to replace a dying second-gen iPad mini. It provides about the same level of performance as the second-gen iPad mini when it was new, although less likely to crash when loading internet pages from a secondary app.

Graphics are nice and smooth, good image resolution, responsive touchscreen. Excellentcameras. Apps and videos load quickly. Sound quality is very clean, even the onboard speaker is crisp. It does occasionally go blind to its WiFi connection, requiring a quick off-and-on-again -- annoying but easy to resolve.

I'm strongly displeased with its word-processing user interface. I do a *lot* of writing -- it's the main reason I need a tablet -- and the way the spell-check/replace function operates is needlessly complicated and frustrating, as is the way the cursor drops in the middle of words rather than finding the nearest end (honestly I could write their QA department a full report on providing smoother function and accessibility for the word-processing UI). There is no way to disable gesture typing -- leading to numerous spelling errors -- and the keyboard (it doesn't matter which style is used, this happens with all of them) is hypersensitive and requires an obtrusive level of precision; I have tried typing with hands and with a fine-point stylus with similar messy results, and had to resolve the issue by purchasing a bluetooth keyboard.

Not a good productivity device on its own; given a good peripheral setup it provides adequate function. I'm hoping future software updates improve things.

(3.75/5) I am writing this review from this tablet. I bought this tablet mostly to use as a comic book reader and for some Internet browsing while on the couch, in bed, etc. My primary device is a gaming desktop computer and I don't always want to be tied to my desk, and I felt my phone wasn't completely adequate for the purposes I mentioned. For my uses I would say it is a very good tablet. It has a nice large 9.6 inch screen, and the colors are bright and vibrant. The overall construction of the tablet feels durable. It has a nice heft to it and feels solid and sturdy. Performance wise it seems quick and responsive so far. I haven't had issues with lag with opening apps or scrolling. I've played a bit of Fruit Ninja and Terraria and both ran smoothly. As far as playing videos it seems serviceable. I tested an episode of Narcos on Netflix and some YouTube videos in 720p, as the resolution of this tablet is 1280x800, and the image quality was as crisp and clear as 720p allows for anyway. Battery life seems to be good so far. I have been able to use it for several hours of reading and Internet use without having to charge the battery. It's also upgradeable to Android 6.0 out of the box, which is a definite plus over some other similarly priced tablets.

Now as for the negatives, as I stated earlier the resolution is 1280x800, which I feel is a tad bit low for a tablet with a 9.6 inch screen. Another reviewer had mentioned being able to see the individual pixels that make up the display. I would say 90% of time, in my uses so far anyway, this has not been an issue. But sometimes, depending on the color composition of the image you are looking at you can see the pixels. Another thing other reviewers have pointed out is the sound quality. It does have only one small speaker, and it honestly doesn't sound all that great but I don't think it's as bad as some other reviewers make it out to be. In my opinion it's about what's to be expected from a low-mid range mobile device such as this. It has a 1.2 ghz Snapdragon processor, and for my uses so far it's been fine, but I could potentially see that being a little slow for some users. I also feel I need to mention that I was able to get this tablet as part of a combo deal where I was only paying around 170 USD for the tablet. For the price I paid I think I got a good deal, but I feel it may be a bit overpriced not on sale/part of a combo deal.

Final thoughts: For my purposes (comic book/e-reader, Internet browsing, and a bit of light mobile gaming) it works very well. If you're planning on using this tablet for listening to music or watching videos/tv/movies a lot, I would maybe recommend also investing in a decent Bluetooth speaker, as the sound quality does leave a bit to be desired. Also another reviewer mentioned something implying their on screen keyboard didn't work until they set it up, mine was working fine right out of the box. Finally, as I mentioned earlier this is a secondary device for me, and for my purposes it works well, and if your needs are similar it would most likely work well for you also. But if you're looking for something to be your primary computing/entertainment device I would maybe recommend spending a little extra on something with a little more computing power, higher resolution, and better sound quality.

My total cost for my first tablet experience (this tablet) is around $300 including leather cover with an integrated keyboard, 128GB SD-card, shipping, stylus and a few nice-ities purchased elsewhere.

I'm comparing my experience with this device to my wife's older 10-inch tablet since hers is the only tablet here similar in size. This Tab-E has a few advantages for me over her older 10-inch tablet: newer OS, larger SD-Card support, more cores, superior stability. Her tablet is superior with a stronger speaker I can hear all the way in our family room from the bedroom--whether I want to or not, hardware menu key that actually works as expected, and costs half the price of this tablet.

I absolutely hate the lack of a hardware menu key on this tablet. Makes it impossible to access menus of apps I already own that do not provide an onscreen app menu key (the three dots in upper corner of newer apps). The Tab-E's physical menu button opens a task switcher, not accesses the app menus of older apps. Must use a Windows keyboard and its feature menu to access the menus of Android devices. Lame. A work around is to enable accessibility menu feature. This puts a floating menu button on your desktop. May block portions of your app since is 'floating.' Between the three of us there are more than six tablets. This is the only tablet lacking an in-app menu button. Dumb design. I've read this is Google's decision. Is the future for everyone. No more app menu buttons on devices. So either carry around a PC keyboard or deal with a floating button covering portions of your desktop :(

Something weird with the mid ranges on this tablet. Must use headphones or external Bluetooth speaker to clearly hear audiobooks, esp if there is competing noise. The fan on my desk totally drowns out the built in speaker. In hindsight music is loud and clear. Pristine clear. So it seems to be an audio range issue.

No HDMI.

Screencasting only works with other Samsung devices. Must spend another $60-$100 to buy an external Samsung supported HDMI Screencasting box. Then you can display your screen on any HDMI TV. Looks like I gave away my Chromecast to my son living on his own just a little too soon. Grrr!!!

**The major strength of this tablet is *stability*. Still hasn't fully crashed or totally locked up once. For that I give it five-stars. More reliable than all other tablets here even my sons larger (and more expensive) 12-inch 'pro' Android drawing setup. However two apps on my Samsung Galaxy Tab E 9.6 act 'crazy' once in a while. FB Reader and Moon+Reader randomly black out the screen and lock up the screen and keyboard from responding. I have to use the 'close all' menu to get control of the device again. Wow. Finally a use for that dumb 'menu' button :p

Am I happy with this tablet? Not entirely. If I bought locally or from a TV shopping channel that allows at least 30-days to test items I might have returned it and bought something cheaper. Probably would have. My frustration level was off the charts. Then again there's something to be said for reliable performance. If performance wasn't so awesome I'd have total buyers remorse. I'm glad I did not return it. Just dislike the lack of a physical app menu button and having to deal with workarounds.

Cheaper tablets might have in-app menu key but you could be giving up reliability to get it. If your apps do not have onscreen menu buttons (the three dots) be aware this tablet might not be for you...unless you don't mind toting around an extra non-Android keyboard or enabling accessibility features just to access app menus.

These are my impressions on Samsung's entry level but nevertheless great tablet in my view as I move into my daughter's 3d month of experiencing it :)

THE LOOKS AND FEEL

"It's a giant phone!!", our daughter said after playing with it for the first time. And she's probably right because, once stripped down to its Android foundations... what else is there?

I was impressed by this model's low weight and thin build. It's not 'the lightest' or the 'thinnest' for sure but it feels good and easy to handle and it looks and feel like a quality product which is 'something' given that it was never meant to be 'top of the line'. The back is very much fingerprint-proof and by the way, Samsung made it easy to attach covers, especially if they are made by Samsung but I believe that you can get away with third parties as well even though I haven't tried one myself.

PORTS, EXPANSION

Starting with 'expansion', you can add up to 128GB through the MicroSD slot which is very much as high as you can afford these days. There's also a micro-USB port and, of course, it supports Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, the works. Oh, and there's an audio out jack as well.

WHAT YOU SEE AND HEAR

You are not going to get super-high-resolution with this device but if your main use is, let's say, playing videos 720p, it's good enough. The 1280x800 resolution translates to 157 ppi which is not bad at all when coupled with the quality of the display. The screen is surprisingly readable even under bright light. I love this tablet's colors with it's super-deep-black blacks and bright whites. Reading angles are pretty good. There is no auto-brightness sensor but, again, you're not paying a lot for this gadget.

Speakers... it depends. They are great for a tablet and there's pretty good separation but I still prefer 'big sound' which, by the way, pipes out easily through either Bluetooth or the audio port.

Cameras again, as expected, lets you take great pictures and shoot videos with vibrant colors and good stereo sound.

OPERATIONS AND OS

I like my set my tablets as close to 'standard' Android as possible. It's not always easy and not everything can be deleted but I was able to at least hide out of sight everything I didn't want. As a near-standard Android 4.4.4 device, I couldn't be more pleased. However, I can't say much about Samsung's own enhancements because I don't really use them.

RATED 'GOOD'

I love the good screen display, the overall feel of 'quality', the efficient Quad-core 1.3 GHz processor, the adequate 1.5GB of RAM and its ease of use. I can't think of anything terribly 'negative' to say other than it not being 'tops' so it's an easy '4 stars' (I like it) for me.
